title: 112_s1286
content: The Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011 is cited as the title of the Act. It includes the extension of Trade Adjustment Assistance. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011 repeals Section 1893 of the Trade and Globalization Adjustment Assistance Act of 2009. It also makes amendments to various sections of the Trade Act of 1974 regarding funding limits and dates. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011 amends various sections of the Trade Act of 1974, changing dates and funding limits. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011 amends funding limits for fiscal years 2011 through 2016 and specifies amounts for a 3-month period in 2016. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011 amended funding limits for fiscal years 2011 through 2016, specifying amounts for a 3-month period in 2016. Additionally, various sections of the Trade Act of 1974 were amended regarding availability of appropriated amounts and specific dates for reporting. Section 2373a(a)(1) was amended to allocate $40,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016, and $10,000,000 for the 3-month period from October 1, 2016, to December 31, 2016. Section 285 of the Trade Act of 1974 was also amended. "Section 285 of the Trade Act of 1974 was amended to include termination provisions." Trade adjustment assistance, vouchers, allowances, and other benefits under chapter 2 will not be provided after December 31, 2016, except for workers certified before that date who continue to meet eligibility requirements. After December 31, 2016, technical assistance and grants under chapter 3 will not be provided, except for those approved before that date through a petition filed under section 251. After December 31, 2016, technical assistance and financial assistance under chapter 6 will not be provided, except for those approved before that date through a petition filed under section 292. After December 31, 2016, technical assistance and grants under chapter 4 will not be provided, except for those approved before that date through a petition filed under section 273. Section 298(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to increase funding levels for technical assistance and grants for fiscal years 2011 through 2016. SEC. 102 of the Trade Act of 1974 specifies the effective date for the amendments made by section 101, applying to petitions for certification and assistance filed after the enactment date. Additionally, TITLE II focuses on improving health coverage, with SEC. 201 addressing the affordability of the credit. SEC. 201 amends the Internal Revenue Code to improve the affordability of the credit by changing the effective date to January 1, 2017. SEC. 202 modifies payment for monthly premiums, and SEC. 203 allows TAA recipients not enrolled in training programs to be eligible for the credit. SEC. 203 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow TAA recipients not in training programs to be eligible for the credit starting January 1, 2017. SEC. 204 establishes a pre-certification period rule for determining creditable coverage lapses. SEC. 205 amends various acts to change the date from February 13, 2011, to January 1, 2017. The effective date for these changes is for plan years starting after February 12, 2011. SEC. 205 amends the Internal Revenue Code and the Workforce Investment Act to change the date from February 13, 2011, to January 1, 2017. The effective date for these changes is for months beginning after February 12, 2011. ERISA, IRC, and PHSA amendments change the date from February 12, 2011, to December 31, 2016, for PBGC recipients and TAA-eligible individuals. The Public Health Service Act is amended to change the date from February 12, 2011, to December 31, 2016, for coverage periods ending on or after February 13, 2011. SEC. 207 amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the coverage date to January 1, 2017. SEC. 208 updates the notice requirements to January 1, 2017. SEC. 301 establishes a required minimum 10-year term for grantor retained annuity trusts. SEC. 207 amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the coverage date to January 1, 2017. SEC. 208 updates the notice requirements to January 1, 2017. SEC. 301 establishes a required minimum 10-year term for grantor retained annuity trusts. Subsection (b) of section 2702 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include additional requirements for grantor retained annuities. The amendments made by SEC. 301 establish a required minimum 10-year term for grantor retained annuity trusts, with specific conditions for the right to receive fixed amounts and the value of the remainder interest. Effective date for transfers made after December 31, 2010. SEC. 401 of the Act ensures compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 by referencing the latest statement on budgetary effects submitted by the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
